description: {"blocks":[{"key":"cmpj2","text":"This protocol uses a python based script and command-line BLASTn to annotate in a final table single-read sequencing results from genome amplifications, within other output files.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"algh4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c2otn","text":"Its main use in our lab (https://biocomputationlab.com) is to identify the location and gene locus of transposon inserts in microbial bacterial genomes of Pseudomonas putida KT2440. However, this script can be used for other bacterial genomes for which its genome sequence and annotation are available.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":155,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":25,"length":29}],"data":{}},{"key":"bofro","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1rtfq","text":"Script was developed and tested in python 3.11.9 with blastn version 2.9.0, sickle version 1.33 and fastqc version 0.11.9","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eqrhf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jjob","text":"This is a description of the LAP entry LAPu-InsertsGenAnnotation-2.0.0 located in the LAP repository, specifically LAPu-InsertsGenAnnotation-2.0.0 and Github Entry LAPu-InsertsGenAnnotation-2.0.0, 2 places that you can download directly the script used and usage examples","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":86,"length":14},{"key":2,"offset":115,"length":31},{"key":3,"offset":151,"length":44}],"data":{}},{"key":"blp5r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f35ln","text":"The major changes from previous version are:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":44}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"de18i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e4rns","text":"File format for -identity Argument: Now accepts XLSX and CSV files.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":34}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eqena","text":"New Argument --summaryMap: Added the --summaryMap argument.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7k5gq","text":"Enhanced -quality Argument: When provided, the merged quality file (FastQC file) will use the file name (without extension) as the sequence identifier, which will match the qaccver in the table_reads_gene_description.csv file.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":26},{"style":"bold","offset":220,"length":1},{"style":"italic","offset":173,"length":7},{"style":"italic","offset":187,"length":33}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"den6h","text":"Support for Numeric Identifiers: Numeric identifiers follow the same rules as well names for locating them in a file or sequence identifier.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":31}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1p3k2","text":"Identifier Pattern for Sequences: The script recognizes the last element of the pattern (+well_, +number_, _well_, _number_) as the sequence identifier for -identity and --summaryMap arguments.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":32},{"style":"bold","offset":182,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1915q","text":"More read extensions accepted: they will be treated as previously txt files are treated for all other arguments","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"21AC3C1F556711EDB33C0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://biocomputationlab.com"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"FFC5B8E64CAE48EFA104C332C048CE7B","url":"http://www.laprepo.com"}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"DB72FCD00E1B496384D8826B6958C09A","url":"https://www.laprepo.com/protocol/bacterial-insertions-in-genome-annotation-using-blastn-v2-0-0/"}},"3":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B0572F3E3D974F449900B3D35DEF6FD5","url":"https://github.com/BiocomputationLab/LAPrepository/tree/5e9c38c629aabe5bdf964e5ce3169ee442131fa5/LAPuEntries/LAPu-InsertsGenAnnotation-2.0.0"}}}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"c47e7","text":"This script needs min 4 arguments in the following order:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fkmhp","text":"Directory of folder containing sequencing reads","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"11rvi","text":"Reads file type (should be FASTA format even if the extension can be anything)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cdsll","text":"Genome file to perform blastn alignment (FASTA format)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4rfab","text":"Genome annotation file (.csv)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"87fkr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ca72","text":"This program, by the time this guide was developed, can only be executed with Linux and macOS systems","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"c0eod","text":"Download reference genome file","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2v6ol","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b0p9u","text":"You can download the genome of the organism that you want to compare to the reading sequences from different sources such as NCBI, GSA or even pages dedicated to the organism (for example pseudomonas.com).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":188,"length":15}],"data":{}},{"key":"8smss","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cecgd","text":"For this script to work, genome files need to be in FASTA format (.fasta, .fna, .ffn, .faa, .frn). Sequence alignment is based in BLASTn which requires FASTA format as input.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":52,"length":12},{"style":"bold","offset":152,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"261DCCFD65604BF29C98CDDDC3C1B58C","url":"https://pseudomonas.com/"}}}}

will provide an example of how to install a WSL in the following {"blocks":[{"key":"5732l","text":"Choose which arguments to run the script","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":40}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"48fvq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4net","text":"This script needs to be performed in a command line window using Python. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c2gsd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7jhb3","text":"Depending on the provided arguments, the program will perform more or less actions such as a quality trimming or variant name annotation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mn47","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fq08","text":"The script requires a minimum of 4 arguments, which we will call from now on the positional arguments. In addition, the program's behaviour can be changed by providing optional arguments. Finally, there is another type of argument that the script can accept, which is for information usage.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":81,"length":20},{"style":"bold","offset":168,"length":18},{"style":"bold","offset":272,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dgocv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7203j","text":"In the following sub-steps, we will define the behaviour, needs and different kinds of arguments.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1men9","text":"Annotation of sequencing results from P. putida KT2440 with only positional arguments","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":85},{"style":"italic","offset":38,"length":9},{"style":"italic","offset":48,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"119dh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bl4b3","text":"This has been done in a Windows 10 with a WSL Ubuntu 20.04","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2pi3d","text":"Download annotation file","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d11nt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7s6o","text":"You can download the annotation of the genome from different sources, such as NCBI, KEGG or pages dedicated to the organism.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6kl5v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fgo5j","text":"For this script to work, the annotation file needs to be in CSV format and need to have at least the following columns with these exact names (names in bold letter):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":152,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9gud","text":"Start - Nucleotide number that sets the beginning of the annotated region","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4t7c9","text":"End - Nucleotide number that sets the ending of the annotated region","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4paj7","text":"Locus Tag - Identifiers that are systematically applied to every gene in a genome. It has to be a unique name","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ekv0k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"89vbt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"43f1o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eb54u","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"du8s5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":20,"offset":171,"style":"bold"}],"key":"7dqj9","text":"If the annotated file does not have those specific columns, but it has the information,the user can change the name of the columns to run the script because it should have exactly those names","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d3vu8","text":"In case your annotated genome is not a CSV file but either a TSV, GFF or GTF, there are software that can convert those types of files to CSV:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2r8fh","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":53,"offset":106}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":10,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":7,"offset":50,"style":"italic"},{"length":4,"offset":62,"style":"italic"}],"key":"aqmc5","text":"GFF to GFT: there are several convertors, such as gffread and AGAT. Some other converters can be found at https://agat.readthedocs.io/en/latest/gff_to_gtf.html","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"length":32,"offset":21}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":10,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":7,"offset":12,"style":"italic"}],"key":"1rf1v","text":"GFT to CSV: gft2csv (https://github.com/zyxue/gtf2csv)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":10,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":7,"offset":116,"style":"italic"}],"key":"e8jj9","text":"TSV to CSV: there are a lot of online converters and Python packages that you can use to convert TSV to CSV, such as pandas","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"3A10F8FC8D4F11EEBD880A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://agat.readthedocs.io/en/latest/gff_to_gtf.html"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"},"1":{"data":{"guid":"159D54558D4C11EEBD880A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/zyxue/gtf2csv"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7p51a","text":"Download sequence files","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8963h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"787qp","text":"Sequence files should be in a folder. Depending on the sequencing company, sequence files will be in .txt, .seq, .fasta or other format. This should be specified in the arguments of the program. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ct6v7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65dl","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ef5ni","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"agqus","text":"Even if the sequence files have different extensions they must follow a FASTA format and each file should contain only 1 record","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eih4q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"enqaq","text":"For more information about the FASTA format visit https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genbank/fastaformat/","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":50,"length":49}],"data":{}},{"key":"c5qdd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fb6js","text":"We need to know from now on that the sequence id of the secuence (the id of the sequence is after the \u003e character in the FASTA format files) does not have to be the same as the name of the file containing that sequence. For example, the name of the file could be aaaa.txt and the sequence id of that sequence \u003eabcd, but we recommend both of them to have the same name.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4kgu5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cgplo","text":"For some actions the name of the file will be taken in account, like when searching for the quality files associated to that sequence; and for others the sequence identifier (SeqID) will be taken in account, like extracting the position of the well in the map indenty file.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bjaej","text":"The sequences that companies provide usually come with other files that give the quality of those reads. These files should also be in that same folder as the sequences if we are going to provide them to the program.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5qo3c","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8sppg","text":"If we also have these files (.ab1, .fastqc, .abi, etc), the user of this program will be able to produce results that are more trustworthy by providing these quality files to the script and trimming the regions that do not have the quality wanted by the user.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bicbk","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":51,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"bmhik","text":"Only qual, ab1 and fastq quality files are accepted","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"1407BA20175F11EFB1290A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genbank/fastaformat"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"528vo","text":"Acquisition of map of reads for annotation of variants","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":54}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4btqr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2t1a9","text":"The identity of each variant can be annotated by using this script if a map of the 96-well plate is provided in CSV or XLSX. It can be created by hand or can be an output file of other LAP entries, such as LAP-PCR-1.0.0","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":206,"length":13}],"data":{}},{"key":"6emrh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7lqkh","text":"This map should be a CSV or XLSX (only the first sheet will be read) file that will contain the names or identities of the sequences that corresponds to the reads. It needs to have the name of the rows and columns of the plate and can only be used if the reads and map fulfill the following requirements:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fahiu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7mho2","text":"There is only 1 map","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":14,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"v69m","text":"All the reads of the directory can be tracked in that map, i.e., the directory of reads should only include the ones in the map. An example, if the map has 12 columns and 8 rows and it is half full (48 identities), the directory of the reads cannot be more than 48 sequences.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":57}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9luqc","text":"All sequences need to have an identity in the map, i.e., the cell correspondent to a well in the map of a sequence cannot be left empty.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":49}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a6pau","text":"The sequence id of the reads need to have the name of the cell between a plus and an underscore if the extension of the files is seq (for example, readSequence+A10_example) or between underscores if the extension of the reads is another one (for example, readSequence_A10_example).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":63,"length":18},{"style":"bold","offset":82,"length":51},{"style":"bold","offset":176,"length":64},{"style":"italic","offset":147,"length":24},{"style":"italic","offset":255,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"g07f","text":"If the identities of the names on the sequences are numbers, the numbers need to be from 1 to 96, any other number will not be able to be tracked to any cell in the map. The numbers will be counted or tracked from top to bottom, left to right, for example, if a sequence id is readSequence_9_example will be tracked to the cell A2","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":65,"length":31},{"style":"italic","offset":277,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"54a1v","text":"If any sequence id has more than 1set of character that can be match with the expression +number_/+well_ or _number_/_well_, the last match will be the one taken as the position  that is going to be searched in the identity
